The above analysis suggests that this exit decision has distinct characteristics as compared with the VC investment and divestment decisions prior to venture IPO that have been the focus of extant research. First, the VC may make a small minority equity investment in a venture,which then provides an opportunity to make subsequent investments to capture the upside potential in the venture. In this case, the initial investment confers a growth option (e.g., Li, 2008). In the context of post-IPO exit, however, the VC has been working with the venture for some time and it is well beyond the stage of option creation. Second, prior to a termination event such as IPO, the VC must decide whether to continue or discontinue funding the venture at each milestone, and such decisions have been analyzed as holding or exercising a withdrawal or discontinuation option (Li & Chi, 2013). After IPO, however, the VC has no obligation to inject more capital, and there is a liquid market to buy and sell venture equity. Third, the exchange option embedded in the VC's exit decision is also distinct from an abandonment or exit option (Ozdemir & van den Ende, 2021). An investor is considered to hold an option to abandon a project when the investor can dispose of the asset with an uncertain value at some salvage price that is assumed to be known (possibly zero) (Chi et al., 1997), and an investor is considered to hold an option to exit when the investor can divest an asset with a known value from continued use at an uncertain price (Dixit, 1989). Because both the VC's valuation and the market's valuation are uncertain and can diverge over time in the presence of information asymmetry, neither abandonment option nor exit option accurately conceptualizes the option held by the VC via retained equity in the newly public venture. For these considerations, it is only appropriate to view the VC's exit decision as holding or exercising an exchange option.2 To our best knowledge, no study in strategy and entrepreneurship has recognized the role of exchangeoptions inVCexitdecisions.  

# 3 HYPOTHESES  

With the conceptual analysis, we advance the idea that a VC's decision to cash out upon venture IPO must account for an additional opportunity cost-the value of the exchange option that is given up in cashing out. The higher the value of the option, the greater the cost of cashing out. The value of the option rises with uncertainty. A higher uncertainty in the valuations by the VC and the market increases the likelihood that the unexpected changes in their valuations will diverge to a greater extent. The exchange option, however, enables the VC to exploit the upside potential by exercising the option under favorable conditions and keep the downside risk in check by holding on to its equity under unfavorable conditions. Hence, an increase in uncertainty raises the value of the option and the VC's incentive to retain equity upon venture IPo.  

The idea of retaining equity under uncertainty to realize the upside potential of the newly public venture resonates with practitioners.3 According to an investment manager in a leading VC firm, a VC usually has a profit target for its portfolio companies, which can be viewed as indicative of the VC's private valuation in our conceptualization. The investment manager is in charge of the decisions on when to sell the equity of portfolio companies, and he notes, “Based on our calculation, we retain equity in those companies that we consider having potential to grow, and sell them later."' In our interviews with VC executives, uncertainty emerges as an important consideration for VCs to retain equity and delay exit. A VC Partner notes, \*We tend to retain partial holdings when the sector is going through a lot of uncertainties on the stock market." We thus hypothesize that:  

Hypothesis H1. (baseline) The higher the industry-level uncertainty for an investee venture, the higher a VC's propensity to remain a significant owner of that venture after its public listing.  

We further submit that the VC's private information reinforces the effect of uncertainty on the incentive to retain equity. As the VC's private information becomes more positive (or less negative) about the investee venture, we expect that the marginal effect of a rise in uncertainty also turns stronger. When the VC possesses positive private information, the VC's initial valuation $V_{0}$ will be higher than the market price $M_{0}.$ prompting the VC to expect that additional information revealed by the venture's performance in the future will cause the market price to converge to the VC's valuation. This, in turn, will increase the VC's incentive to retain equity for the opportunity to sellit at a higher price later. Because higher uncertainty means larger random changes in $M_{t}$ and $V_{t}$ over a given time increment, a rise in uncertainty enlarges both $\Delta{}V_{t}$ and $\Delta{M}_{t}$ and thus makes it likely for $M_{t}$ to catch up with and exceed $V_{t}$ sooner.4 In the meantime, when the VC's private information is more positive, there is a higher chance for information newly revealed to the public to be positive and further increase the likelihood for $M_{t}$ to catch up with and exceed $V_{t},$ enabling the VC to sell the equity at a higher price sooner. Therefore, we expect that the positive effect of uncertainty on the net payoff of retaining equity will increase with the VC's positive private information.  

The VC's private information, by definition, is not readily observable to outsiders. Our empirical strategy is to find observable factors indicating that the VC is likely to possess or have access to private information that is inaccessible to general market participants. First, the venture's portfolio of patent applications that are yet to be granted at the time of the exit decision (but ultimately granted) represents a positive signal ex ante that is likely difficult to assess by general market participants, especially before certification by the patent-granting agency (Levitas & Chi, 2010; Schwartz, 2004). Second, at the industry level, a positive market surprise in the returns of firms in the industry is likely to indicate a heightened degree to which public information on the growth prospects of the firms in the industry lags behind the positive private information held by insiders (e.g., the VC).  

## 3.1 I  Patent-related private information and VC exit under uncertainty  

We focus on a venture's portfolio of patents that were still at the application stage in the year of the exit decision but received approval subsequently. VCs recognize the value of new ventures' patents, and patent applications in particular (Lemley, 2001; Mohammadi & Khashabi, 2021). While granted patents are largely public information, pregranted patent applications constitute a reasonable indicator of the insiders' positive private information about the value-creating potential of the venture assets. Whether patents serve as an isolating or appropriation mechanism in the product market (Rumelt, 1984; Teece, 1986) or offer future investment opportunities in the product and factor markets (Levitas & Chi, 2010; Oriani & Sereno, 2011), there is inevitably market friction in the valuation of such proprietary assets (Mahoney & Qian, 2013). Even though the market is forward-looking and anticipating the future value of the venture's patent applications (Hall et al., 2005), knowledge is asymmetrically distributed (e.g., Hayek, 1945), especially before the grant of a patent by the legal authority that serves to verify and accentuate the value-creating potential of the venture's proprietary knowledge. Even though a larger portfolio of patent applications sends a positive signal about the future performance of a newly public venture, such a signal may not be sufficiently visible or credible in the eyes of general market participants before the patents are granted and made fully public. A vC with equity stakes in the venture, meanwhile, should have better assessment on the value of the pre-grant patents because of access to inside information and accumulated knowledge about the venture's capabilities.  

Hence, possession of private information on patent applications likely enables the VC and the entrepreneur to recognize the value of the patent applications more fully as compared with the market. Even though a large portfolio of patent applications can be expected to boost the market's valuation of the venture as well, we expect that it will have a smaller impact on the valuation of the market because the market is likely to find the intrinsic value and the signaling value of the patents more difficult to verify. The value of a patent application will eventually be recognized by the market as the patent is granted and as the venture turns the proprietary knowledge into commercial success in the future. But until then, the divergence of valuations between the VC and the market remains, and it will likely widen as the portfolio of the venture's patent applications increases. The number of the venture's patent applications can thus serve as an indicator of the extent to which the VC possesses positive private information. Hence, we hypothesize:  

Hypothesis H2. The positive effect of uncertainty on a VC's propensity to remain a significant owner of an investee venture post-IPO is greater when the venture has a larger number of patent applications atthetimewhenexitbecomesfeasible.  

## 3.2 I  Market surprise and VC exit under uncertainty  

The market anticipates the future earning potential of the venture and other firms in the industry, and incorporates such expectation in the current stock prices, according to the efficient market hypothesis (Fama, 1970). But the market can only do so imperfectly. There will always be discrepancies between the actual returns and the forecast returns despite the progress in predicting the returns of industries (e.g., Fama & French, 1993). These discrepancies are market surprises. The market may not account for the surprises fully in the current stock prices for some period of time because of the difficulty for general market participants to obtain accurate information on the value-creating potential of at least some major firms in the industry. In other words, the extent of surprises reflects the extent of private information that affects at least a significant portion of the firms in the industry.  

Market surprise can be positive or negative. The more positive the market surprise (i.e., the larger the actual returns turn out to be than the prior forecast returns), the more the market has been underestimating the upside potential of the firms in the industry. On the other hand, the more negative the market surprise, the more the market has been overestimating the earning potential of the firms in the industry. While a market surprise in general suggests that the VC willikely have private information, the positivity (negativity) of the market surprise makes it more likely that the VC has a higher (lower) valuation of the venture's assets than the market, at least for some period of time until the market absorbs the new information.5 Positive market surprise can thus serve as an indicator of the extent to which the VC possesses positive private information. We hypothesize:  

Hypothesis H3. The positive effect of uncertainty on a VC's propensity to remain a significant owner of an investee venture post-IPO is greater when the stock prices of firms in the venture's industry exhibit amorepositivesurprise.  

# 4| METHODS  

## 4.1  | Empirical setting  

We test our theory with data on VC exit after venture IPO in China. The VC industry in China started in the 1980s but it did not take off until late 1990s and early 2000s (Batjargal & Liu, 2004).It has become one of the largest VC markets since 2001 (Guo & Jiang, 2013). VCs may sell their ownership stake in newly public ventures in one of two ways: by selling their shares on the open market and paying proceeds to investors (i.e., limited partners) in cash, as in Australia (Hsu et al, 2020), or by distributing shares to investors, as is frequently the case in the Us (Gompers $\&$ Lerner, 1998). In China, VCs generally sell shares and pay investors in cash, as confirmed by the expert scholar we interviewed. In addition, VCs face a legally compulsory lockup period in China. Once the lockup period expires, the VC has the discretion as to whether and when to cash out or retain equity before the end of the fund life. Our interviews with three VC executives in September 2017 indicate that the exit decision is usually made around the lockup expiration date (a few months before or shortly after). Further, according to our interviews of five experts in 2022- 2023, it generally takes 6 months to 1 year for investors to cash out after lockup expiration, a time window that is also reported in prior research (e.g., Cumming & Maclntosh, 2003). The VC can negotiate for an extension of one to 2 years within the fund lifespan. This arrangement between the VC and the limited partners can be described as, for example, $^{\leftarrow}5+2+1$ ” indicating 5 years of investment, 2 years for exit (including the one-year lockup period), and 1 year of extension for exit. We examine both the likelihood of retaining equity within 1 year after lockup expiration and the rate of exit or cashout within 2 years after lockup expiration.  

Our empirical design with a focus on the China context carries several unique advantages. First, as an emerging market in our sample study period, China has experienced high uncertainty in both its industrial sectors and security markets recently (Luo, 2003); real options tend to be valuable in such settings. In addition, information asymmetry remains severe in emerging markets (Sanders & Boivie, 2004). For these reasons, China offers a proper setting to test our theoretical predictions. Second, as compared with voluntary lockup in countries like the Us (Field $\&$ Hanka, 2001), the mandatory lockup in China allows us to control effectively for any potential confounding effect of strategic lockup behavior (Arthurs et al., 2009; Brau et al., 2005; Brav & Gompers, 2003) on the post-IPO exit decision. Third, focusing on a single country helps control for the effect of the legal environment, which is shown to have significant impact on VC governance and exit (e.g., Cumming et al., 2006; Cumming & Walz, 2010). Finally, our focus on China allows us to examine the impact of the unique institutional setting on VC exit post-IPO, including the role of government, corporate and foreign VCs, as well as political connections, which we discuss below.  

## 4.2 | Data and sample  

We collected data on the VC-backed ventures that went public in the Chinese stock market. Data come primarily from the PEData database (Gu & Lu, 2014), and are augmented with data from WIND (e.g., data on financial information and IPOs that were not included in PEData) and IPO prospectuses (e.g., data on shareholding and VCs that were not included inPEData).?  

Our analysis focuses on VC-backed ventures that went public during 2009-2012. Important for our purpose, the largest number of VC-backed ventures in China went public on the GEM board, which did not come into existence until October 2009.8 China has periods of IPO freeze, and 2009-2012 is the latest period when private companies were allowed to go public before we started to collect data in 2016. This latest round of IPO offers a sufficient time window to observe the post-IPO exit events. Given the lockup period of 1-3 years and at least another year or two for exit, we need 4 to 5 years to observe post-IPO exits after lockup. We updated information onVCexit in2019 and2022.  

We hand collected information on VC exit from company IPO prospectuses as well as quarterly and annual reports. A VC fund's shareholding in a venture is reported as far as the VC remains on the top 10 shareholder list for that venture. We obtained each VC fund's ownership at the time of a venture's IPO from the IPO Prospectus. We then tracked the change in each VC fund's equity holding position in that venture on a quarterly basis during 2009- 2017, from the time of venture IPO until 2 years after the lockup expiration date, assuming 1 year for exit and 1 year of extension. Our initial sample includes 437 IPO ventures. After excluding observations with incomplete information, the final sample includes 407 ventures financed by 506 unique VC funds, involving 777 VC fund-venture dyads.

### 4.3.1 | Dependent variable  

We generated a dummy variable that takes the value one if a VC fund retains at least some of its equity holdings and continues to appear on the top 10 shareholder list 1 year after the IPO lockup expiration date (e.g., Cumming & Maclntosh, 2003). If the VC fund disappears from the top 10 shareholder list for two consecutive quarters within 1 year after the lockup expiration date, we view it as a case of cashout (i.e., full exit), and the dependent variable takesthevaluezero."

### 4.3.3 |  Patent application-related private information  

We collected patent information for ventures from the State Intellectual Property Office (SIPO) of China (http:// www.sipo.gov.cn/), the Chinese counterpart of UsPTO. We extracted patents for each venture and then manually checked to ensure the accuracy and comprehensiveness of the data based on venture name and location. The Patent applications measure is the number of patents filed for by a venture but not yet granted in the year of lockup expiration. Although these patents were ultimately granted, they remained largely private information for insiders such as entrepreneurs and VCs at the time of application. We used the application or filing year in calculating the measure (Hall et al., 2001). We used the patent applications at the time of lockup expiration rather than at the time of venture IPO to address the possibility that the IPO might be timed to patent filing and that more information could be learned or disclosed during the lockup period. This measure is venturespecific and time-varying.  

### 4.3.41 Market surprise  

In line with prior work (e.g., Kogut, 1991), we first established a long-term base-rate for each industry's historical returns and then looked at year-to-year departures from this trend. We forecast the returns for each industry each month for time t using data up to time t-1. We then calculated the difference between the actual returns at time t and the predicted returnsfor time t.Predicted returns are derived from estimation of the Fama-French model similar to Equation (1) above but with returns as the dependent variable (e.g., Kogut, 1991). The average difference for the 12 months leading up to the exit event is then used as a proxy for market surprise. We focused on the exit year since information further away from the exit decision will not likely contain much “surprise." We obtained the average for 12 months to smooth out any undue influence of unique situations in recent months. The higher the value of this measure, the more positive the market surprise. This measure is industry-specific and time-varying.  

### 4.3.5 | Controls  

We account for several prominent alternative explanations for the VC's decision to retain equity after venture public listing. For the information and signaling arguments, we include the following variables commonly used to measure information asymmetry in the VC context (Cumming & Maclntosh, 2003; Gompers, 1995). First, younger ventures and earlier-stage ventures tend to have less observable track record and there willikely be higher information asymmetry between such ventures and the market. VCs' decision to retain equity after venture IPO may add certification and endorsement value at the time of IPO or afterward. It is also worth noting from a property rights perspective that VCs may have an incentive to seek greater control in younger and earlier-stage ventures when their long-term performance remains unclear (Aghion & Tirole, 1994). Age at lockup expiration is the log of duration from the venture's founding date to the lockup expiration date. The unit of measurement for duration is years (e.g., an age of 18 months is 1.5 years, same for all duration variables below, unless specified otherwise). Earlier stage at IPO takes the value one if the venture is at the seed or early stage of development based on the PEData data, and zero otherwise. Second, the venture may underprice its initial offerings to signal its quality (Allen $\&$ Faulhaber，1989; Welch, 1989). The argument is that only high-quality firms can bear the costs of selling stocks below the market expected value. Underpricing is the percentage increase in the closing price over the opening price of the venture's stock on the first trading day. Finally, patenting is often considered a signal of the quality of a firm's technological assets (Hsu & Ziedonis, 2013; Svensson, 2007). From an information signaling perspective, if the venture's patents serve as an effective signaling mechanism, they may reduce the benefit of using retained equity in the venture postIPO to signal the quality of the venture's assets, or patents may increase the signaling value of retained equity as they are from different signaling sources (Courtney et al., 2017).  

Founder human capital is important in VC investments (Fuller & Rothaermel, 2012; Haeussler et al., 2019; Matusik et al., 2008; Pollock et al., 2009). Higher founder ownership in a venture gives the founder more discretion to pursue value-creating activities and indicates the founder's greater confidence in the venture's future. Such discretion and confidence are difficult for general market participants to observe and evaluate, but the VC as an insider does not face as much difficulty in observing, assessing and monitoring the venture. It is hence reasonable to expect that founder ownership will increase a VC's propensity to retain equity. We measure founder ownership using the percentage of equity shares controlled by the founder(s) and their families at the time of IPO (Paeglis & Veeren, 2013). Data on founders and their shareholding come from WIND and IFIND.  

At the VC-venture dyad level, we include investment duration, staging and syndication that are relevant to information asymmetry concerns at the time of IPO (e.g., Cumming et al., 2006; Lerner, 1994). Longer investment duration implies more involvement of the VC in coaching and monitoring, which can reduce the information gap between the VC and the entrepreneur and may lower the need for retaining equity. Staging provides additional monitoring as each round of funding is usually contingent on the venture reaching a specified milestone, and may thus reduce the need for retaining equity. Syndication of multiple VC funds facilitates deal screening and due diligence pre-IPO and may lower the need for retaining equity post-IPo.  

The VC may use retained equity in the IPO venture to balance risk and return in its portfolio of investment projects. Because the majority of portfolio companies are usually yet to be sufficiently developed for IPO, the risks involved in these assets are largely undiversified. A larger portfolio of ventures also means greater need for capital infusion. It is thus less desirable for a VC to retain significant equity stakes in a venture post-IPO when the VC maintains a larger portfolio. VC portfolio is the log of number of unique portfolio companies the VC has funded in the last 3 years up to the lockup expiration year. Data come from PEData.  

The VC may not have a choice but to cash out if it is cash constrained. In our interviews with VC executives, cash constraint has often emerged as an important consideration for post-IPO exit strategy. Absent exact information on cash inflow and outflow, we expect that cash constraint will be lower if the VC has a greater amount of capital under management. The VC needs to have sufficient capital to finance other promising ventures if it decides not to cash out of the newly public venture. Based on data from PEData, VC capital under management is the log of millions of RMB (Chinese currency) for each VC fund prior to the lockup expiration date, and if missing, is replaced by (1) the value available closest to the lockup expiration date, and (2) imputed value based on a linear regression on industry dummies given that the funding need and VC capital are usually industry-specific.  

More experienced and skilled VCs may face less cash constraint and have less pressure to raise a follow-up fund (Buzzacchi et al., 2015; Cumming et al., 2009), both of which may increase the propensity to retain equity. In addition to VC portfolio size we discussed above, two more variables are created, VC number of IPO exits and VC number of funds, which can be viewed as proxies for VC experience and skill(and even reputation in case of number of venture IPO exits) (Cumming & Dai, 2011; Nahata, 2008). Because VC number of funds is highly correlated with both VC portfolio $(r=0.82^{\circ}.$ and VC capital under management $(r=0.62^{\circ}.$ , we did not include the variable in our final analysis, but we performed a robustness test by including or excluding the variable, and it does not alter the results.  

The VC will face more pressure to sell out if the fund reaches the end of its life span (Kandel et al., 2011), which is typically around 10 years (Fenn et al., 1997)-even though in some cases, a fund can be extended (especially upon a successful exit) or a follow-on fund may be established, according to prior research (lliev & Lowry, 2020) and our interviews. From PEData, VC fund age is the log of the duration from the VC fund's founding to the lockup expiration. In addition, the VC may need more time to sell shares if it holds significant equity ownership in the IPO venture, because dumping large shares of equity after venture IPO may drive the share price down. We control for VC blockholding by creating a dummy variable that is equal to one if the VC holds $5\%$ or more of theventure at the time of IPO.  

China has its unique formal and informal institutions, as reflected in the prominent role of the state and political connections. These unique institutional attributes affect the VC investment process from deal selection, to monitoring and advising, to exit and IPO (Ahlstrom et al., 2007; Batjargal $\&$ Liu,2004;Bruton $\&$ Ahlstrom,2003).The institutional impact on VC exit post-IPO remains largely unexplored. First, we control for whether a VC fund is owned or controlled by the government (GVC) (Devarakonda & Liu, 2023; Murtinu, 2021; Suchard et al., 2021), and whether a VC fund is a subsidiary of an industrial enterprise (CVC) (Dushnitsky & Yu, 2022; Huang & Madhavan, 2021). Second, social ties, especially political connections, can bring information, resource, and legitimacy benefits (Hillman, 2005; Li & Zhang, 2007; Peng & Luo, 2000; Wang, 2016; Zhao & Lu, 2016). Current research indicates that political connections of ventures and VCs can enhance the likelihood of obtaining approval for IPO (Bao et al, 2016; Wang & Wu, 2020) and increase the amount of capital raised at IPO in China (Wu et al., 2013). We manually collect the biographic information on each senior executive (partners, directors, senior managers) serving in a VC from its website, professional databases (Tianyancha and Qichacha), and Baidu (equivalent of Google in China). We then create a dummy variable that is equal to one if any senior executive of the VC once served in a government agency or public office, as a member of National or Local People's Congress, as a member of People's Political Consultative Conference, or as a senior administrator in a government-supported research institution (e.g., Ba0 et al., 2016; Wang & Wu, 2020).  

In the China context, firm behavior may be shaped by the status as a state-owned versus a private enterprise. The dummy variable, state-owned, takes the value one if the focal venture is categorized as state-owned by the Wind database, and zero otherwise. Companies can voluntarily list their shares in one of two locations in China: Shenzhen and Shanghai, with GEM as part of the Shenzhen stock exchange. We include a dummy variable, Listed in Shenzhen, to account for unobservable location-specific fixed effects.  

We include several other control variables in our estimation. At the VC level, we control for whether a foreign VC is involved.Foreign VCs tend to have the expertise and capital to fund new ventures in China (Ahlstrom et al.,2007; Bruton& Ahlstrom,2003).At the venture level, we control for the size of the venture,measured as the log of the market value at lockup expiration. Market value is calculated as the closing price in the lockup expiration year, multiplied by the total number of shares based on data from the WIND database (in millions of RMB). At the dyad level, lockup duration is the log of the time passed from the IPO date to the lockup expiration date. Finally, for all the estimations, we include industry dummies (based on the Shenyin Wanguo Securities industry classification) and year dummies to account for industry fixed effects and unobservable time-varying effects. In particular, a proper test of the uncertainty effect in the real options logic requires that we tease out the industry fixed effects to focus on theunpredictablepart of the industry effects.  

### 4.4 | Statistical model  

We specify a logit model to test the likelihood of retaining equity versus cashing out within 1 year after lockup expiration(Cumming $\&$ Maclntosh, 2003). Suppose a VC makes the exit decision depending on the expected net payoff:  

$$
\pmb{V}^{*}=\pmb{X}\beta+\varepsilon,
$$  

where $V^{\ast}$ is the vector of net payoff values that is unobservable to an empirical researcher and remains a latent variable. $\pmb{X}$ is thematrixof explanatoryvariables, $\beta$ is thevector of regressioncoefficients,and $\varepsilon\backsim{\mathcal{N}}(0,\sigma^{2})$ is the vector of regression errors. What we can observe is a binary variable depending on whether the VC retains equity $(=1)$ or cashes out $\scriptstyle(=0)$  

$$
V_{i}=\left\{{1\atop{0\nmid{\uparrow V_{i}^{*}=0}}}\right.
$$  

where $V_{j}$ denotes the observed values, with $\dot{I}=1,2,\cdots,N$ and $V_{j}^{*}$ is the threhold value that can be understood as when the market's valuation exceeds the VC's valuation by the value of the exchange option. So, the observed data can be used to estimate a limited dependent variable model such as logit. Let us assume the log odds is a linear function of our explanatory variables, $\begin{array}{r}{{10g}\Big(\frac{p}{1-p}\Big)=\pmb{X}\beta}\end{array}$ .We can then estimate a logit model as follows:  

$$
P(y=1|x)=\frac{\exp(X\beta)}{1-\exp(X\beta)}
$$  

where $\pmb{P}(\pmb{y}=1|\pmb{x})$ is the likelihood of the VC retaining equity relative to cashing out conditional on the set of explanatoryvariables $\pmb{x}.$ The model is estimated with the maximum likelihood approach. Since a VC fund may invest in multiple ventures in our sample, we apply the robust procedure and cluster the observations by VC funds to obtain the variance-covariance matrix for coefficient estimates. The results remain when we alternatively cluster the observationsbytheexityear.  

The interaction effects of uncertainty and private information variables on the predicted probability in Equation (4) for each observation can be computed as follows (Norton et al., 2004):  

$$
\frac{\partial^{2}P}{\partial x_{1}\partial x_{2}}=\beta_{12}P(1-P)+(\beta_{1}+\beta_{12}x_{2})(\beta_{2}+\beta_{12}x_{1})P(1-P)(1-2P).
$$  

We further specify a Cox hazard model to estimate the rate of exit or cashout within 2 years after lockup expiration. Since VCs usually have closed funds with a fixed lifespan (e.g., 7-10 years),they will ultimately divest all their holdings in investee ventures. It is thus important to understand the time to exit. For this purpose, we estimate the rate of exit, as proxied by the rate of VCs disappearing from the top 10 shareholder list. The exact date of any share sale that results in a cashout is unknown, and the remaining equity stake held by a VC that disappears from the top 10 list, if any, also remains unknown. To overcome these data limitations, we track the quarterly reports for 2 years after lockup expiration and calculate the number of quarters that have passed from the lockup expiration date to the last quarter when a VC appears as a top 10 shareholder of an IPO venture. By the end of 2 years, VCs have indeed disappeared from the top 10 list for about $97\%$ of the 777 dyads. Analysis of the Schoenfeld residuals suggests that the model meets the proportional-hazards assumption $(\chi^{2}=44.77,p=0.81)$

Let us turn to the variables related to the information and signaling arguments. As shown in Models 1 and 6 of Table 3, some of the variables such as venture earlier stage, age, investment duration, staging and syndication have statistically insignificant effects. VCs are less likely to retain equity of underpriced IPO ventures, but more likely to retain equity in ventures with higher founder ownership. These two variables have no significant effects on the rate of exit. Finally, number of patent applications increases the likelihood of retaining equity but has no significant effect on rate of exit. Overall, these findings present a mixed picture for the information and signaling arguments, a finding that is echoed by prior research (Cumming & Maclntosh, 2003).

Part of the reason could be that many CVCs in China share a similar objective as independent VCs to pursue consumption-based growth from market opportunities rather than pursue innovation-based growth from high-technology ventures (Dushnitsky & Yu, 2022). The extent of VCs' political connections has a statistically insignificant effect. Finally, there is no statistically significant effect for state-owned ventures, ventures listed in Shenzhen, and foreign VC-backed ventures. Future research may compare the role of unique institutional settings in VC exit decisions across countries.

### 5.1.1 | Alternative explanations  

We examine several other explanations for the VC decision to retain equity or cash out. We present the results for the logit estimations. A VC may face human capital constraint if it is to delay exit. Human capital is a fixed resource in limited supply and cannot be expanded easily. Human capital constraint may limit the attention of the fund managers, dilute their value-added services, and even reduce their ability to monitor and advise (e.g., Cumming, 2006; Fulghieri & Sevilir, 2009). We scaled VC portfolio size by the total number of fund managers for each VC (e.g., Cumming & Walz, 2010) and scaled VC capital under management (e.g., Cumming & Dai, 2011) by the number of funds and the total number of fund managers for each VC. The higher the scaled measures, the greater the human capital constraint, and the less likely a VC will retain equity. We collected data on fund managers from corporate websites, online search via Baidu and Tianyancha. Despite our painstaking efforts, we were only able to obtain data for 182 VCs and 535 observations of our sample. In Model 1 of Table 4, VC portfolio has a negative effect on the likelihood of retaining equity, which is consistent with the portfolio argument to balance risk and return and with the cash constraint argument about having sufficient capital to finance portfolio companies. The scaled VC portfolio variable has a statistically insignificant effect. In Model 2, VC capital under management, which is an inverse indicator of cash constraint, has a positive effect as expected, and the coefficient of the scaled VC capital variable is statistically insignificant. These insignificant results do not appear to be driven by collinearity as the correlations are all below 0.45. Nevertheless, the results should be interpreted with caution because of the large number of missing values and the fact that data on VC fund managers are largely time-invariant except for four VCs.  

VC fund performance may influence risk preferences and incentives of a VC, which in turn may affect its exit decision. First, individuals exhibit risk-seeking behavior in choices involving sure losses (Kahneman & Tversky, 1979). Fund managers with poor performance have less to lose and continuing ownership in the venture gives the VC a chance to achieve its reference point (Bock & Schmidt, 2015). Second, VCs typically earn a $2\%$ management fee that is based on the total capital raised from limited partners, plus $20\%$ of carried interest from profitable investments. This compensation structure may incentivize fund managers to make investment decisions based on prior performance (liev & Lowry, 2020). Specifically, fund managers with poor performance may have more incentive to undertake high risk, for example, by staying with the investee venture rather than cashing out-they face little downside if continuing ownership does not pay off, but substantial upside if it does. Extant research has measured fund performance in terms of net fund cash flows (Bock $\&$ Schmidt, 2015), but such information is unavailable in our dataset. IRR may be used to evaluate VC fund performance (Kaplan $\&$ Schoar, 2005) with some caution (Weber et al., 2016), but it is only available when a VC fund exits. Since both the risk preference and incentive arguments suggest that higher performance would be positively associated with cashing out, it can be inferred from these arguments that those that retain equity willikely have lower performance. With this assumption, we generated a dummy variable that is equal to one if the IRR is larger than the median of the sample. Results in Model 3 of Table 4 show that our main results remain largely the same but that the IRR measure is statistically insignificant. This result needs to be interpreted with the limitations of the measure in mind.  

### 5.1.2| Alternative model  

We have so far analyzed retaining equity relative to cashing out, without distinguishing retaining some equity (i.e., partial exit) from retaining all equity (i.e., no exit). A small number of VC funds in our sample chose not to exit at all (see Table 1) and six increased shareholding post-IPO within 1 year after lockup expiration. We estimate a multinomial logit model to compare no exit, partial exit and full exit (i.e., cashout). The multinomial method is proper as the three alternative choices are conceptually distinct but not necessarily ordinal (Long & Freese, 2006; McFadden, 1973). As Models 4-6 of Table 4 show, the main effect of uncertainty remains, as do the moderating effect of patent applications for the comparison of partial exit and full exit, and the moderating effect of market surprise for the comparison of no exit with partial and full exits. These findings are broadly consistent with our arguments.  

### 5.1.3  | Alternative sample  

A VC may drop out of the top 10 shareholder list not because of the VC selling shares but because of others increasing shareholding that dilutes the VC's equity stake. To check the potential influence of such cases, we collected historical data on the equity stake of the top 10 shareholders for each quarter between 2009 and 2016 from the WIND database. For each VC that dropped out in the current quarter, we compared its shareholding percentage in the previous quarter with the shareholding percentage of the shareholder that has the least shareholding percentage among the top 10 in the current quarter. If this shareholder's current shareholding is more than the VC's previous shareholding, the VC may have dropped out due to this shareholder's increased shareholding. Indeed, we found 18 such cases of VCs dropping out. Among them, 14 VCs were holding less than $1\%$ ofshareswhentheydropped out. We performed a robustness test by removing these 18 cases from the sample. Model 7 of Table 4 shows that this doesnot alter ourresults.  

### 5.1.4 |  Unique institutional setting  

We examined whether the effect of uncertainty is contingent on the unique Chinese setting that is characterized by the prominent roles of GVCs, CVCs, political connections, and foreign VCs. While GVCs tend to retain equity, the likelihood of retaining equity is significantly reduced under higher uncertainty (Models 8 of Table 4). These results probably indicate that government VCs face less financial constraint but are more risk-averse. The interaction effects of CVCs, political connections, and foreign VCs are insignificant.  

We included industry dummies in our analyses for a proper test of the real options logic. Different motivations may underline IPOs in different industries. For illustration, as compared with IT and computer companies, biotechnology firms may operate in a revenue-negative status at the time of considering an IPO (Guo et al., 2o04). As shown in Model 9 of Table 4, VCs are more likely to retain equity in the medical sector, but there is no significant difference betweenthecomputerindustry andothersectors.  

# 6 I DISCUSSION AND CONCLUSION  

This study identified a previously unrecognized driver for a VC to remain a significant owner in an investee venture after venture IPO: to retain the opportunity to benefit from the upside potential of the IPO venture under uncertainty. We developed a real options framework to capture this intuition by conceptualizing the decision to retain equity or cash out as holding or exercising an exchange option. Real options studies in management and entrepreneurship tend to rely on heuristics from models of standalone options such as options to defer, grow, abandon and exit (Li et al., 2007; Trigeorgis & Reuer, 2017). Each of these options is usually conceptualized as a choice between a known value and an uncertain value, that is, the value of an asset to be acquired or divested versus the price at which the asset can be acquired or divested. In the case of a VC's exit from a newly public venture, however, both the VC's valuation and the market's valuation are subject to uncertainty and evolve stochastically over time. So, any option embedded in the VC's equity stake cannot be properly analyzed as a standalone option in our context. Our conceptualization not only allows us to characterize correctly the option held by the VC via retained equity in the IPO venture but also enables us to analyze how the VC's exit decision is influenced by both uncertainty and private information, the two factors that enhance the value of the exchange option. Our empirical analysis offered support for this real options view, after we accounted for a large number of factors, including signaling, cash and human capital constraints, blockholding, portfolio diversification, institutional settings (e.g., GVC, CVC, political connections), and industry-andtime-fixedeffects.  

This study offers an integrated framework to combine the real options logic with the information economics view by highlighting the reinforcing effects of uncertainty and private information on strategic behavior. Extant research has invoked information asymmetry as a key condition motivating the VC to retain equity stake in a newly public venture because the commitment to doing so can send a positive signal to the market about the VC's confidence in the venture (Cumming & Maclntosh, 2003). This view, however, is based solely on the VC's possession of private information, and does not incorporate the role of uncertainty that remains prominent for newly public ventures and in VCs' exit decision. This view also leaves out the interaction between uncertainty and information asymmetry. Hence, it cannot uncover the role of the exchange option as an opportunity cost of cashing out or the effect of uncertainty per se on the decision. In this regard, our theoretical framework incorporates both uncertainty and private information, extends the insights from the information economics view, and enhances our understanding of the drivers in the VC exit decision after venture IPO. In our analysis, the interaction effect of uncertainty and private information provides discriminating evidence for the proposed real options framework.  

In our empirical analysis, we employed two variables as proxies for information asymmetry between insiders (e.g., the VC) and outsiders: the venture-level patent applications and industry-level market surprise. The results indicate that each of these factors can enhance the positive effect of uncertainty on the VC's propensity to retain equity after venture IPO, in support of our predictions. These results have interesting implications. First, patenting is typically considered to send a credible signal to the public about a firm's technological competitiveness in future (Levitas & Chi, 201o). But patent applications may also increase the information asymmetry between insiders and outsiders, raising the VC's likelihood of retaining equity and decreasing the rate of exit. Second, market surprise has been viewed as a cue for investors to assess the growth potential of firms in an industry (Kogut, 1991). Our study suggests that such a publicly visible cue may also indicate a gap between insiders and outsiders in their valuations of firms in the industry and raise the value of any exchange option that may have been embedded in the insiders' equity stake. Future research may shed light on the implications of market surprise on decision making in other contexts such as corporatedivestitures.  

Our findings have interesting implications for practice. In our interviews, VC executives were well aware of the importance of uncertainty and market volatility in their exit decisions. As for information asymmetry, they pointed primarily to the importance of signals for pre-IPO investment decisions and the venture IPO decision, but less so for post-IPO exit decisions. Both our theoretical framework and empirical analysis suggest that private information may play another role in the exit decision in reinforcing the effect of uncertainty. The message is clear: VCs need to take into account both uncertainty and private information in their exit decisions after venture IPO.  

We note several areas where the study can be extended. We analyzed the role of exogenous industry uncertainty in our theorization and empirical analysis. Such a focus allows us to examine closely the interaction between uncertainty and private information. Extant research has shown that different sources of uncertainty, such as technological and demand uncertainty, may have differential effects on market valuation of R&D (Oriani $\&$ Sobrero, 2008). Research has also pointed to the distinction between technical and cost uncertainty (Pindyck, 1993) as well as that between ex0genous and endogenous uncertainty (Folta, 1998; Li et al., 2007; McGrath, 1997). Recent entrepreneurship research also suggests distinct effects of perceived effect uncertainty and response uncertainty (Zhang et al., 2021). A more fine-grained analysis of different sources and types of uncertainty may bring additional insightsto a decision context like ours.  

While the options-based rationale for retaining equity is generalizable to other contexts, an emerging VC market such as the one in China in our sample period is unique because it has a relatively young VC sector characterized by rapid growth and substantial uncertainty and information asymmetry. It also has unique institutional settings. Comparative analysis across countries may uncover systematic differences, if any.  

In conclusion, this study offers a novel explanation for VCs' exit decision after venture IPO. The exchange option perspective that we developed allows us to incorporate the concepts of uncertainty and information asymmetry into a broader theoretical framework. Both figure prominently in many decision contexts but their interaction has largely eluded research so far. The insights from our theoretical framework can be applied to analyze a broad range of exit and possibly entry decisions in strategic entrepreneurship that involve two parties with divergent valuations under conditions of uncertainty and information asymmetry. We also hope that the study stimulates further work in real options research that incorporates other important concepts such as information asymmetry to gain insights on strategic entrepreneurship questions (Li et al., 2007; Trigeorgis & Reuer, 2017).

# Is it worth it? The rates of return from informal venture capital investments  

Colin M. Masona\*, Richard T. Harrisonb,1  

aDepartment of Geography, University of Southampton, Southampton SO17 1BJ, UK Centre for Entrepreneurship,Deparment of Management Studies,University of Aberdeen, AberdeenAB243QY,UK  

Received 1 April 1999; accepted 1 August 2000  

# Abstract  

Despite growing interest in venture capital, there is a paucity of information on the rate of return to these investments and the limited research that is available refers almost entirely to portfolio returns for venture capital funds. The investment returns to business angels have been virtually ignored. This paper provides the first attempt to analyse the returns to informal venture capital investment using data on 128 exited investments from a survey of 127 business angel investors in the UK. The paper finds that the distribution of returns is highly skewed, with $34\%$ of exits at a total loss, $13\%$ at a partial loss or break-even, but with $23\%$ showing an IRR of $50\%$ or above. Trade sales are the main way in which business angels harvest their investments. The median time to exit for successful investments was 4 years. Large investments, large deal sizes involving multiple coinvestors, and management buyouts (MBOs) were most likely to be high-performing investments.  

$\copyright$ 2001 Elsevier Science Inc. All rights reserved.  

Keywords: Venture capital; Business angels; Investment performance; Harvest; Capital gains tax; Business failure  

## 1. Executive summary  

There is a paucity of reliable information on the returns from venture capital investing. The available evidence on the investment performance of venture capital firms is limited to a small number of studies and some highly aggregated figures produced by national venture capital associations. Information is even more limited in the case of the informal venture capital market. The objective of this paper is to fill this significant gap by examining the returns achieved by business angels, the ways in which they harvested their investments and the length of the holding period.  

The most appropriate benchmark against which to compare the performance of investments by business angels is with the returns achieved by venture capital fund managers. However, this is extremely problematic. The standard measure of performance in the venture capital industry is the internal rate of return (IRR) of the fund. This takes account of cash-oncash returns from the sale of shares and disbursements (e.g., dividend payments) plus the share of the residual value of the fund's holding in cash and investments in portfolio companies that have not been realised, net of management fees. However, business angels do not invest by means of a dedicated fund and tend to think about investment performance in terms of capital gains multiples on each investment that they make. The most appropriate basis for evaluating the investment performance of business angels, and for comparing the investment performance of business angels and venture capital funds, is therefore on a dealby-deal basis, with the returns measured simply in terms of the multiple achieved and the length of the holding period.  

Information on the investment performance of business angels is derived from 127 usable responses from a mail survey of business angels in the UK. Only 51 of the 101 respondents who had made investments had actually exited from any of these investments. In total, these investors had exited from 128 investments. It is these investments that are the focus of this paper. The calculation of the investment performance did not take account of any income that the investors might have received from dividends or fees. As a consequence, this may inflate the proportion of exits that are recorded as losing money and reduce the proportion that broke even or generated positive returns. Comparative data on the investment performance of venture capital funds was obtained from Murray (1999). This provides deal-specific investment performance data for three early-stage technology specialist UK venture capital funds. Such a comparison is far from ideal, and any conclusions should therefore be regarded as tentative. However, the availability of comparative information is severely restricted as venture capital funds are normally unwilling to release information on the performance of their individual investments.  

Business angels and venture capital funds differ in a host of ways, including investment experience, resources, governance, investment philosophy and objectives, and the approach to investment decision-making. This, in turn, provides the basis for anticipating clear differences in the investment performance of business angels and venture capital funds. However, the nature of these differences is open to competing interpretations.  

This paper tests three hypotheses.  

Hypothesis 1: Business angels will have a poorer investment performance than venture capital fund managers.  

This hypothesis is based on the greater investment experience of venture capital fund managers, the noneconomic considerations that business angels take into account when making investment decisions, differences between business angels and venture capital funds in terms of approaches to investment appraisal, due diligence and contracting, and the deeper pockets of venture capital funds.  

Hypothesis 2: Business angels will have a systematically superior investment performance to that of venture capital fund managers.  

This hypothesis is underpinned by three factors. First, one of the key differences between business angels and venture capital funds is that fund managers have an obligation to invest whereas business angels, who are investing their own money, do not. Investing under time pressure is likely to lead to suboptimal investment decisions that can be expected to result in some bad investments. Business angels can be more selective because they do not have to invest. Second, business angels can devote more time to supporting their investee companies and their entrepreneurial background enables them to make a more effective contribution. Third, because of adverse selection problems, the aggressive valuation stance adopted by venture capital funds results in inferior deals.  

Hypothesis 3: Business angels and venture capital funds will have different returns profiles because of differences in their approaches to managing risk.  

The returns profile of business angels will approximate a normal distribution. Because most business angels make only a small number of investments, they have limited ability to reduce their risk through diversification. Business angels therefore concentrate on avoiding bad investments rather than seeking winners and aim to make a return on every investment they make.  

The returns to informal venture capital in the UK are negatively skewed: $34\%$ of exits took place with a total loss of the investment and a further $13\%$ generated either a partial loss or broke even in nominal terms; only $10\%$ generated IRRs in excess of $100\%$ . This investment performance is significantly different from that of venture capital funds. Hypothesis 1 cannot be supported. Business angels have a lower proportion of investments in which they lose money, which is consistent with Hypothesis 2, but this hypothesis cannot be fully supported because business angels and venture capital fund managers have similar proportions of highperforming investments. Hypothesis 3 receives the strongest support. Although negatively skewed, the returns to informal venture capital deals are less skewed than those of early-stage venture capital deals. Business angels have fewer investments in which they lose money but a significantly higher proportion of their investments either break-even or generate only modest returns. This is consistent with the argument that business angels will be more concerned to avoid bad investments than to find winners. However, Hypothesis 3 cannot be fully supported as the proportion of very successful investments (IRRs of $100\%$ and over) made by business angels is similar to that of venture capital funds.  

Trade sales are the main way in which business angels harvest their investments. These were used for successful investments as well as some that only broke even. IPOs accounted for only a small minority of exits. Exits from “living dead’ investments have been primarily through sales to other shareholders or new third party shareholders.  

The median holding period was 4 years. However, this varied by investment performance. For investments that generated a satisfactory or exceptional return the median holding period was 4 years. However, the median holding period was 2 years for lossmaking and break-even investments and 6 years for investments that generated low positive returns.  

Management buyouts (MBOs), large deals involving multiple coinvestors, and deals involving large amounts of follow-on investment are the most likely to generate very high returns (IRR of $50\%$ and above). However, by no means did every high-performing investment have these characteristics.  

The findings have important implications for policy-makers. The need to improve the availability of early-stage venture capital has been recognised by national governments and the European Commission. The key conclusion for UK policy-makers is that the findings support the recent introduction of a capital gains tax (CGT) taper for investors in unlisted companies, the effect of which is to reduce the amount of capital gains that is charged to tax on the disposal of business assets. This taper was originally set at 10 years when introduced in 1998, which was out of line with the time horizon over which business angels typically invest, but was reduced to 4 years in the 2000 Budget. More significantly, the evidence presented in this paper — that the risks outweigh the rewards for business angels, with the proportion of investments generating zero or negative returns exceeding those that return a significant multiple on the original investment — suggests that stimulating the supply of informal venture capital may need a richer cocktail of tax incentives than merely a reduction in CGT, including front-end tax reliefs and even venture capital guarantees.  

## 2. Introduction  

There is a paucity of reliable information about the returns from venture capital investing. Institutional venture capital firms do not generally make public any information about their actual returns and hence most of the research has been restricted to the performance of the small minority of venture capital firms that are publicly quoted (e.g., Kleiman and Shulman, 1992; Manigart et al., 1992). In one of the very few in-depth studies of the performance of limited partnerships — the most common organisational form adopted by venture capital firms — Bygrave et al. (1989) found that for funds formed in the period 1969 to 1985 the mean IRR peaked in 1982 at $27\%$ , but overall returns were typically below $20\%$ . This confirms earlier, less detailed, studies that found that “rather than the folklore figure of $30\%$ to $50\%$ , actual venture capital returns have most often been in the teens, with occasional periods in the $20\%$ to $30\%$ range and rare spikes above $30\%^{\prime}$ ， (Bygrave and Timmons, 1992, p. 153). In Europe, because of the sensitivity of returns information, analyses have been conducted by national venture capital associations and the European Venture Capital Association (EVCA). These studies lack transparency in the process of analysis (Wright and Robbie, 1998). A recent EVCA study of the overall returns on mature venture capital funds across Europe found that buyout funds generated the highest returns with a median IRR from inception to the end of 1996 of $15.5\%$ . This figure is three times that earned by funds specialising in early- and development-stage investments $4.5\%$ and $5.5\%$ , respectively). The superior performance of funds specialising in MBOs and MBIs is confirmed by studies of the UK, French, Dutch, and Italian venture capital industries (Wright et al., 1998; Burgel, 2000).  

Relatively few investments in the portfolios of venture capital funds produce large gains. Thus, the overall performance of a fund is crucially dependent on the presence of a small number of very successful investments. These investments are the ones that are generally harvested by means of an IPO (Bygrave and Timmons, 1992). An analysis by Venture Economics of 383 investments harvested by 13 venture capital funds in the period 1969 to 1985, reported by Bygrave and Timmons (1992), noted that just $6.8\%$ of investments returned 10 times or more on the invested capital whereas over $60\%$ lost money or failed to exceed the savings account rate. Almost $50\%$ of the final total value of the funds came from just $6.7\%$ of investments. This study also noted that early-stage investments produced proportionately more winners (a return of five times or more on the original investment) and more outright losers than investments in expansions or LBOs/acquisitions. This negatively skewed pattern of returns is also found in a study of the portfolios of three early-stage UK venture capital funds (Murray, 1999).  

There is virtually no information on investment performance in the informal venture capital market —— which is the main source of risk finance for businesses at their seed, startup, and early growth stages, particularly where small amounts of finance are sought (under $\pounds250,000/\cup\mathbb{S}\mathbb{S}500,000)$ (Freear and Wetzel, 1990; Freear et al., 1995; Mason and Harrison, 1994; Sohl, 1999). Although some studies have identified the expectations of business angels, in terms of their exit horizon, method of exit, the rate of return, and proportion of ‘winners’ and “losers’ (Wetzel, 1981; Tymes and Krasner, 1983; Mason and Harrison, 1994), there has been just one study of the actual returns achieved by business angels. This study, based on responses from 39 active business angels in Finland who had made a total of 49 exits, found that $20\%$ of investments had made a significant return (IRR in excess of $20\%$ $13\%$ had made moderate returns, $13\%$ broke-even, and the remainder $(56\%)$ lost money (Lumme et al., 1996, 1998). The investment performance of business angels therefore remains an issue where Wetzel's (1986, p. 131) call for research that can “put boundaries on our ignorance'” remains appropriate.  

The objective of this paper is to fill this significant void in our knowledge of the informal venture capital market by examining the returns achieved by business angels, the ways in which they harvested their investments, and the timing of their harvest. The paper is based on deal-specific information rather than on the portfolio measures of performance used in previous venture capital studies. It seeks to answer four basic questions about the informal venture capital market that, because of difficulties in assembling the necessary data, have not previously been answered.  

· What returns do business angels achieve from their investments and how do these returns compare with the performance of ‘professional’ venture capital investors? · How long do business angels wait before harvesting their investments? · How do business angels harvest their investments? · What are the characteristics of the best performing investments?  

The next section of the paper considers the methodological issues involved in measuring the performance of venture capital investments and in comparing the investment returns of business angels and venture capital funds, and describes the data sources used. This is followed by a consideration of how the performance of business angels might compare with that of venture capital fund managers. Later sections present information on investment performance in aggregate and by type of investment, the methods used by business angels to harvest their investments, the timing of the harvest and the characteristics of high-performance investments.  

### 3. Methodological issues and data sources  

The standard measure to assess performance in the venture capital industry is the IRR of the fund. This takes account of cash-on-cash returns from the sale of shares and disbursements (e.g., dividend payments), plus the share of the residual value of the fund's holdings in cash and investments in portfolio companies that have no publicly traded shares, net of management fees (Bygrave and Timmons, 1992; Burgel, 2000).2 This is an inappropriate method for assessing the performance of investments in the informal venture capital market because business angels do not invest by means of a dedicated fund and so do not have “idle cash', as venture capital funds have. Rather, they think about their investment performance in terms of capital gains multiples on each investment they make (Wetzel, 1994). The implication is that the evaluation of the investment performance of business angels must be undertaken on a deal-by-deal basis, with the returns measured very simply in terms of the multiple achieved and the length of time taken to realise the return. This, in turn, means that the only basis for comparing the investment performance of business angels and venture capital fund managers is also on a deal-specific basis. However, appropriate data are rarely available to permit such a comparison to be made. Venture capital funds do not normally make information available on the performance of individual investments in their portfolio and where such information is available it is difficult to make a like-for-like comparison with the investment performance of business angels because of the specialised investment focus of most venture capital funds. This paper has been able to assemble data on the performance of investments by business angels and has used information from Murray (1999) on the performance of investments made by three UK early-stage venture capital funds to make what is inevitably a tentative comparison.  

Research on the informal venture capital market is hampered by the difficulties involved in identifying business angels. There are no directories of business angels, their investments are not publicly recorded and most strive to preserve their anonymity, hence, researchers have typically had to rely upon samples of convenience. The information on the investment performance of business angels is derived from 127 usable responses from a postal survey of over 10oo business angels who were registered with business angel networks (BANs) in the UK. These organisations operate like ‘dating agencies', providing a communication channel that enables business angels to review investment opportunities while preserving their anonymity and allows entrepreneurs seeking finance to present their investment opportunity to a large number of potential investors (Harrison and Mason, 1996; Van Osnabrugge and Robinson, 2000). The managers of 19 BANs agreed to distribute questionnaires to investors registered with their service.? In addition, some questionnaires were sent to investors who were identified through recommendations and informal contacts. It was not possible to calculate a meaningful response rate because it is not known how many investors are members of more than one network nor the number of investors registered with BANs who are not business angels.  

This methodology is open to three potential sources of bias. First, although many thousands of active and potential business angels are registered with the 48 BANs that are currently in operation in the UK (BVCA, 1999), these investors may not be typical of the overall population of business angels. Van Osnabrugge (1998) suggests that there are few differences between business angels who are members of BANs and those who are not. However, any attempt to test the representativeness of a sample of business angels runs up against the problem that the population of business angels is unknown and probably unknowable (Wetzel, 1983). To counteract the bias inherent in drawing samples from just one BAN (Mason and Harrison, 1997) the sample has been drawn from a number of different types of networks (large and small, local, and regional, private, and public) in various parts of the country. Second, there may be a problem with response bias. However, this could not be tested because no information was available on the characteristics on nonrespondents. An alternative method of testing for nonresponse bias is to compare early and late respondents (Freear et al., 1994). This was not possible either because the various BANs sent out the questionnaires at different times. Third, there are inevitable questions concerning the reliability of self-report data. The main concern is with the ability of respondents to accurately recall the financial details of their investments. Another possibility is that respondents will exaggerate their successes and downplay their failures, although there are no a priori reasons for believing that this will have occurred.  

The questionnaire asked investors to report on all the investments that they had made in unquoted companies. Investors were asked to give details of the year that the investment was made, company characteristics (industry, technology, stage of business development, location), investment characteristics (amount invested, presence and type of any coinvestors, follow-on investment), and exit information (year of exit, method of exit, return multiple on a cash-on-cash basis). Where an investment was still held, investors were asked to indicate the anticipated performance.  

The vast majority $(87\%)$ of the respondents had made at least one investment. In aggregate, the respondents to this survey had made a total of 372 investments. The sample is quite well balanced between those who have made just one or two investments $(37\%)$ and more experienced investors who have made four or more investments $(33\%)$ (Table 1). However, only 51 of the 101 respondents $(51\%)$ who had made investments had actually exited from any of their investments. In total, these investors had exited from 128 investments. It is these investments that are the focus of the paper. These 51 business angels have been the more active investors in the sample: although accounting for just over half of all respondents who have made investments $(51\%)$ they have made two-thirds all investments $(67\%)$  

Furthermore, the most active investors have made the most exits. Those who have made four or more investments, who account for one-third of investors in the study, have made almost three-quarters of all exits (Table 1). The likely explanation is that the more active investors have been investing for longer and so have had more time in which to make exits.  

In view of the link between investment characteristics and performance (Bygrave and Timmons, 1992), it is appropriate at this point to briefly note the main features of the sample of 128 investments that are the subject of this paper. In terms of vintage, the dates of the investments range from 1961 to 1996, but most were made in the 1990s $(38\%)$ or 1980s $(48\%)$ . The earliest exit was made in 1966, but $90\%$ occurred after 1985 ( $77\%$ since 1990). The investments were made in a wide range of different industries: $44\%$ were in manufacturing with a further $16\%$ in finance and business services, $13\%$ in other services, $9\%$ in retail and wholesale, and $7\%$ in consumer services. There is no particular concentration in terms of stage of investment: $23\%$ of investments were at start-up, a further $23\%$ at the early stage, $21\%$ were in established businesses, and $16\%$ at the seed stage. The remaining $17\%$ of investments were in MBOs/MBIs. Finally, $60\%$ of investments were in London, the South East and the Eastern region, the most economically prosperous regions of the UK.  

For the purpose of this study, the IRR for each business angel investment was computed very simply, using an Excel spreadsheet, as an annualised figure derived from the multiple on the original investment and the length of time that the investment was held (i.e., the time value of money). It should be noted that this calculation of IRRs did not take into account any income that investors might have received from dividends, or fees paid for performing a nonexecutive chairman or director role or for consultancy services. In some cases, these running returns may accumulate over time to match or even exceed the amount initially invested (Mason and Harrison, 1996; Lengyel and Gulliford, 1997). The effect of excluding this information may therefore be to inflate the proportion of exits that are recorded as total or partial losses and reduce the proportion that broke even or generated positive returns. The exclusion of running returns will also tend to depress the positive IRRs recorded for successful exits. Accordingly, the results provided in the remainder of this paper are likely to underestimate the rates of return from informal venture capital investing in the UK.

### 4. The investment performance of business angels and venture capital fund managers: alternative hypotheses  

Business angels and venture capital fund managers differ in a host of ways, including investment experience, resources, governance, investment philosophy and objectives, and the approach to investment decision-making. This, in turn, provides the basis for anticipating clear differences in the investment performance of business angels and venture capital fund managers. However, the nature of these differences is open to competing interpretations.  

The first hypothesis is that business angels will have a poorer investment performance than venture capital fund managers. Specifically, the upside returns from their investments will be limited compared to those of venture capital fund managers. Hypothesis 1 is supported by the following arguments.  

First, venture capital fund managers are much more experienced investors than business angels. In a comparison of the two types of investors, Van Osnabrugge (1998) reports that venture capitalist fund managers have made an average of 23 investments compared with 4 by business angels, and on average manage a portfolio of 10.3 investments compared with 2 by business angels. Other studies confirm that the majority of business angels have made three or fewer investments (Mason and Harrison, 1994; Coveney and Moore, 1998). However, business angels have significantly more entrepreneurial experience than venture capital fund managers (Van Osnabrugge, 1998), although this experience is likely to be confined to a particular industry or market segment. Fiet (1995) suggests that this detailed industry/market knowledge enables business angels to reduce their exposure to market risk. In practice, business angels often do not make use of this advantage, frequently investing in sectors where they do not have direct experience (Kelly and Hay, 1996; Van Osnabrugge,1998).  

Second, venture capital fund managers raise their finance predominately from large financial institutions such as pension funds, banks, and insurance companies, and have a duty of care when investing this money. Their investment decisions are therefore based on purely economic considerations. Business angels, in contrast, are investing their own money and so are not responsible to anyone else for how it is invested and for what reasons. The return on investment is a major motivation for business angels but it is not the sole motivation (Wetzel, 1981; Mason and Harrison, 1994; Lumme et al., 1998). They also want to have fun while making money (Benjamin and Margulis, 1996). Wetzel (1981) reports that some business angels are influenced by “hot buttons’ and both Wetzel (1981) and Sullivan (1994) note that some business angels are willing to make a trade-off between financial and nonfinancial returns. Their investments may also have spillovers to their other activities. In other words, the financial return on any particular investment made by a business angel does not necessarily capture their full return.  

Third, there are also differences between business angels and venture capital fund managers in terms of approaches to investment appraisal, due diligence, and contracting (Van Osnabrugge, 1998). Many of these arise because business angels, unlike venture capital fund managers, decide on the worth of a potential investment as principals, rather than as agents and/or employees (Feeney et al., 1999; Prasad et al., 2000). Business angels are less concerned with financial projections and are less likely to calculate rates of return. They do less detailed due diligence, have fewer meetings with entrepreneurs, are less likely to take up references on the entrepreneur and are less likely to consult other people about the investment. Conversely, business angels are more likely to invest on ‘gut feeling'. On average, business angels also spend less time negotiating. Venture capital fund contracts are more comprehensive and more likely to include restrictive covenants. Business angels are less concerned about exit routes at the investment stage, whereas this is a much higher priority for venture capital fund managers (Table 2). These differences would again seem to be directly attributable to the fact that business angels are investing their own money whereas venture capital fund managers are investing funds that have been provided by financial institutions and so have a duty of care.  

Finally, a further important distinction between business angels and venture capital fund managers is in terms of their investment capacity. In most cases business angels will not have pockets as deep as those of venture capital fund managers. As a consequence, business angels may be unable or unwilling to provide investee businesses with the further rounds of funding necessary for growth. This has two potential implications for the performance of their investments. First, if they are not in a position to provide follow-on finance to an investee business that needs a further round of investment this will put them in a weak negotiating position vis-a-vis an incoming investor regarding the valuation of their equity stake and may result in a significant dilution of their initial investment. Second, if the investee business is unable to raise additional finance it may become undercapitalised, with adverse consequences for its growth prospects and, in turn, the returns to their investor.
